metadata.title: Hearing Loss, Conductive  Adults

ICD-10 codes.H90.11: conductive hearing loss, unilateral, right ear, with unrestricted hearing on the contralateral side
ICD-10 codes.H90.12: conductive hearing loss, unilateral, left ear, with unrestricted hearing on the contralateral side
ICD-10 codes.H90.2: conductive hearing loss, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: An adult presents with mild, moderate, moderately severe, severe, or profound hearing loss in one or both ears as the result of damage, disease, or injury to external or middle ear Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Obstruction of the external auditory canal (e.g., cerumen, debris)(1)
Swelling of the lining of the external auditory canal(1)
Atresia (absence or malformation) or neoplasms of the external auditory canal(1)
Disruption of the ossicular chain (e.g., idiopathic necrosis, infection, trauma)(1,19)
Otosclerosis (abnormal hardening and fixation of the bones in the middle ear)(1)
Fluid or scarring in the middle ear(1)
Cholesteatoma (a slow-growing  cyst caused by abnormal skin growth that can destroythe ossicles and normal ear tissue)(1)
Sclerosteosis (a rare skeletal dysplasia marked by progressive bone thickening andsclerosis of the skeleton, especially of the skull)(21)
Osteomas (benign neoplasms) of the middle ear(25)
risk factors: Allergies, a cold or flu, sinusitis, or a history of middle-ear infections(1)
Turner syndrome (cholesteatoma occurs with higher frequency in patients with Turner syndrome compared to the generalpopulation)(26)

overall contraindications precautions: Contact a physician if there is evidence of an ear infection or excess cerumen
Monitor hearing in both ears for progression of hearing loss
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the patient have a history of hearing loss? When did the hearing loss begin? What is the underlying cause of the hearing loss?

course of treatment.medical management: What medical management has the patient received for this and other conditions? Has the patient had surgical intervention to correct the underlying cause of the hearing loss? Surgery can improve hearing ability by up to 20 dB in patients with congenital stapes ankylosis(4) For patients with damage to the ossicular chain, surgical repair via an ossicular chain reconstruction can restore hearing in some patients(27) Stapedotomy is a surgical intervention to improve hearing in patients with conductive hearing loss due to otosclerosis causing a fixed stapes(28) Tympanoplasty is a surgical procedure to improve hearing in patients with conductive hearing loss resulting from damage to the tympanic membrane(29)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  An audiologist performs a complete audiological evaluation to determine 1) the nature of the hearing impairment (e.g., conductive, sensorineural, or mixed), 2) the severity of the impairment (e.g., mild, moderate, severe, profound; unilateral or bilateral), 3) the anatomy of the impairment (external ear, middle ear, inner ear, or central auditory pathway), and 4) the etiology of the impairment.(1) Usual tests performed by an audiologist for this condition include the following:
Pure tone audiometry (air-conduction  and bone-conduction thresholds)

To assess hearing acuity for pure tones to establish the presence and severity of hearing impairment, unilateral vs. bilateral loss, and the type of hearing loss (e.g., sensorineural vs. conductive)(1)
Speech audiometry to assess speech perception
The speech reception threshold (SRT) is the intensity at which the patient can correctly repeat 50% of the words presented(2)
Tympanometry to assess the impedance of the middle ear in response to sound to diagnose middle-ear  effusions(1,18)

Rinne and Weber tuning fork tests to distinguish conductive hearing loss from sensorineural hearing loss by determining if the patient hears better by bone or air conduction.(1) A patient with conductive hearing loss will hear sound better (louder) through bone conduction versus air conduction(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had an audiological evaluation, aural rehabilitation, or speechlanguage  therapy for this or other conditions and if past treatments were helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: For the purpose of the differential diagnosis, the audiologist may examine if the hearing loss is accompanied by tinnitus (perception of ringing or high-pitched  noise), vertigo, imbalance, aural fullness, otorrhea (ear discharge), headache, facial nerve dysfunction, or head/neck paresthesias.(1) An audiologist must also determine the situations in which the patient has most difficulty hearing (e.g., noisy room, restaurant)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -What is the patient’s ability to hear in the presence of background noise? -What is the patient’s ability to localize sound? -Can the patient hear with one ear better than the other?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables such as sinus infection, noise in the environment
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, ringing in the ears) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe ____________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient previously experienced hearing loss? Does the patient have a history of familial hearing loss?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other medical issues, if relevant
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs), taking care to note any potentially ototoxic medications
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient require communication for work? Does the patient’s job require extensive communication? Is the patient required to speak on the telephone? Does the patient participate in sports or hobbies that require communication?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any limitations that the patient has with ADLs; document any use of adaptive equipment. Does the patient currently use a hearing aid, cochlear implant (for mixed sensorineural/conductive losses), or other amplification system? If so, is equipment in working order?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify specific situations in which the patient has difficulty communicating

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document if the patient has used or currently uses hearing aids or other amplification systems; note if hearing aid use is unilateral or bilateral. Typically, for a conductive hearing loss, a hearing aid or amplification system needs to allow for sound to bypass the outer and middle ear and be delivered directly to the inner ear via the boneA hearing aid that amplifies sound by carrying it through the bone in the skull, bypassing the external and middle ear(5)Surgically implanted devices that use an abutment embedded in the skull to transmit sound by direct conduction through bone to the inner ear, bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear(5,6,7) -Authors of a systematic review found 11 observational studies on bone-anchored  hearing aids for individuals with bilateral permanent conductive hearing loss that met inclusion criteria for data extraction and analysis. Results of the systematic review indicated that bilateral bone-anchored  hearing aids provided greater objective and subjective benefit compared to unilateral bone-anchored  hearing aids. Researchers noted that there was a limited number of studies available with good-quality  evidence; hence further research was recommended(22) -In a study conducted in China, researchers investigated the efficacy of unilateral bone-anchored  hearing aids in Mandarin-speaking  patients with bilateral aural atresia. Researchers reviewed the charts of 16 patients aged 6 to 28 years with bilateral conductive hearing loss resulting from bilateral aural atresia who underwent implantation of unilateral bone-anchored  hearing aids. Postoperative tests of hearing indicated an overall mean improvement of 38.3 dB, which was a statistically significant improvement(24)The Vibrant Soundbridge (VSB) is a middle = ear implant system that consists of an externally worn audio processor and a surgically implanted component that consists of two parts, the vibrating ossicular prosthesis (VORP) and the floating mass transducer (FMT). Authors of a systematic review that included 19 studies on the VSB concluded that it was both safe and effective for treatment of conductive hearing loss due to middle-ear  pathology(17) –Cochlear implants are sometimes helpful for patients with permanent forms of conductive hearing loss. A cochlear implant is a device that provides direct electrical stimulation to the auditory nerve of the inner ear. For detailed information on cochlear implants for adults, see Clinical Review…Cochlear Implants in Adults ; CINAHL Topic IDT708998
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: A speech-language  pathologist (SLP) or audiologist can administer a survey to determine the perceived impact of the hearing loss on the patient’s quality of life –The Hearing Satisfaction Scale (HSS) is a validated instrument used with patients with conductive hearing loss. It measures patient satisfaction with his or her hearing under different circumstances (e.g., parties, telephone) and was designed to be used in clinical studies but can also be used to measure clinical outcomes(8) –The Hearing Handicap Inventory for Adults (HHIA) is a 25-item  scale designed to quantify psychosocial perceptions related to hearing loss and to identify the effects of hearing loss on employment(9) –The Hearing Handicap Inventory for the Elderly (HHIE) is a 10-item, self-administered  questionnaire designed to assess the emotional and social effects of hearing loss in older adults. It can be used by an audiologist to assess the patient’s readiness to use a hearing aid or other assistive device(10)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Does the patient have any problems with communication other than hearing impairment? Assess appropriate area (i.e., speech, language, voice) as necessary

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

To ensure relevance and appropriateness of the treatment program addressing the effects of hearing loss, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient/caregivers, other healthcare professionals, and educational professionals as appropriate

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Speech-language  treatment or aural rehabilitation might be warranted if the patient or patient’s partner can benefit from instruction in specific communication strategies to compensate for hearing loss
assessment plan of care.rule out: Etiology will be determined by an audiologist or an otolaryngologist. The evaluator will rule out or diagnose sensorineural or mixed loss
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: An audiologist will primarily be involved in aural rehabilitation activities, which might include hearing aid orientation and use, group support programs, speech-reading  programs, provision of assistive listening devices, perceptual training to improve speech perception and communication, and counseling to enhance participation and cope with limitations.(11,12) An SLP might assist with communication-related  goals. For patients with otosclerosis, an otolaryngologist might perform a stapedectomy (replace stapes with titanium or other material).(23) Some patients with otosclerosis are candidates for bone-conduction  hearing aids or cochlear implants. Refer to an otolaryngologist if there is cerumen or fluid buildup or tympanic membrane (eardrum) rupture. Refer to an oncologist or otolaryngologist if there is evidence of cholesteatoma or neoplasm
treatment summary: Clear speech –Several studies have shown that the use of “clear speech” (e.g., slowing speech rate, pausing, keyword identification, and placing acoustic stress on key words)by a conversational partner increases speech recognition by the person with the hearing loss(13,14) –Researchers who conducted a study in Canada found that specific instructions to a subject (patient’s partner) (45 min/1 session) on how to produce clear speech by slowing speech rate, pausing, keyword identification, and placing acoustic stress on key words led to more consistent use of clear speech even in postintervention follow-up  sessions (1 month) when compared to another subject who was simply instructed to “speak clearly”(15) –Other adaptive techniques include facing patient directly to make sure you have his/her attention, speaking at a normal volume while enunciating (without using exaggerated lip movement), avoiding covering mouth with hand, and making sure that the patient’s hearing aids are in place and in working order and that eyeglasses are worn(10)

Home education programs –In a randomized clinical trial researchers in the Netherlands examined the effects of an instructional program with videotapes on 46 patients and their partners(16) -The authors of this study reported that the experimental group made use of communication strategies and had an increased positive attitude (e.g., “enjoyment of life”) immediately after intervention and at 6 months after intervention . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Difficulty understanding conversational partnerIncrease understanding by instructing conversational partner on the use of “clear speech”Clear speech _ _ See Treatment summary , above _A single intervention session can be enough to instruct a conversational partner on how to adapt and maintain clear speech so that the patient with hearing loss has better speech recognitionSpeech adaptations should be practiced and used in the home  Difficulty understanding; lack of knowledge of hearing loss and amplification optionsEnhance communication and increase knowledge about nature and consequences of hearing loss for patient and partnerHome education program _ Home education on the effects of hearing loss may include videotapes or personalized instruction outlining different communication strategies (e.g., speech reading, clear speech) in various situations and information on how to use hearing aids and other technical devices(16) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveIt is expected that the patient and patient’s conversational partner will become increasingly familiar with the communication strategiesThis program is intended to be used as a home-based program to educate patients with hearing loss and their partners .

improved quality of life: HSS: a validated instrument used to measure patient satisfaction with his or her hearing under different circumstances (e.g.,parties, telephone)(8)
HHIA: a 25-item  scale designed to quantify any posttreatment change in psychosocial perceptions related to hearing loss(9)
HHIE: a 10-item,  self-administered  questionnaire to assess the emotional and social effects of hearing loss. It can be usedto assess posttreatment attitude change toward hearing loss(10)

maintenance or prevention: The patient should consult the audiologist for information on prevention of conductive hearing loss
patient education: See "Conductive Hearing Loss" from the American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association at https://www.asha.org/public/hearing/Conductive-Hearing-Loss/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
